concept.title: Customer Attributes - Beta Program
concept.shortdesc: Customer Attributes let you enrich Analytics data with customer or visitor attribute data from a customer relationship management (CRM) database. You can create customer record sources, then upload customer records to the Marketing Cloud via an Adobe-provided FTP site. As part of the Master Marketing Profile, this service manages the importing and distribution of attribute data in the Marketing Cloud.

conbody.p: Useful attributes commonly stored in CRM databases include age, gender, loyalty level, products own, interests, and Lifetime Value. Customer attributes allow marketers and analysts to answer questions such as:

ul.li: Which online campaigns are most effective with my gold-level customers?
Which products do gold-level customers search for versus platinum-level customers?
Is my site redesign having a positive impact on conversion rates for older customers?
What products do customers with a low lifetime value tend to research on my site?

section.title: Synching the Customer ID with your Analytics Implementation
section.p: When a visitor authenticates on your website or otherwise identifies himself, you must expose that person's CRM customer ID to your Analytics implementation. This synchronization stores that visitor's CRM customer ID in the Marketing Cloud, and activates that visitor's attributes for use in the Marketing Cloud.

For example, assume that Bob has Customer ID 52mc210tr42 in your CRM system. When Bob authenticates on your site, you must expose this ID on the page, and use the ID to synchronize it by one of two means:

ul.li:
Call visitor.setCustomerIDs({"crm_id":"52mc210tr42"}) using the Visitor ID service.
Or,
Populate the Customer ID (52mc210tr42) in a prop or eVar.

section.p: The Customer ID must be set on each Analytics server call where the Customer ID is known.

section.title: Migrating to the Marketing Cloud Visitor ID Service
section.p: Adobe recommends that all Marketing Cloud customers migrate to the Visitor ID service as soon as possible. See Marketing Cloud Visitor ID Service for information about the benefits of the Visitor ID service, how it works and how to implement it.

Participation in the customer attributes beta does not strictly require that you implement the Visitor ID service, but is highly recommended. If you choose to do so, you can implement a portion of your pages for the beta. You will have a six month grace period to upgrade across all properties.
section.note:
To simplify the implementation of the MAC Visitor ID service, use dynamic tag management. If you use dynamic tag management, a temporary work-around is required if you need to configure custom settings for sequencing.
See Dynamic Tag Management MACID Custom Settings (PDF).

section.title: Uploading Attributes Data
section.p: As a beta tester you will need access to CRM or similar data from your enterprise. The data you will upload to the Marketing Cloud via FTP or sFTP must be a CSV file using the following form:

entry.p: F
Platinum
M
Gold

section.p: Customer ID: This column contains the unique identifier your CRM uses for each person in your database. The remaining columns are attributes that come from your CRM. You will choose how many attributes to upload. The beta will support anywhere from one to hundreds of attributes per Customer ID. Most testers will likely upload 20 or fewer attributes per customer record, but you may choose to upload more if desired.
Friendly, readable names are recommended for the column headings, but not required. When you validate the schema after upload, you can map friendly names to the uploaded rows and columns.

row.entry: Five attributes per Marketing Cloud Organization.
1,000 limit per IMS Org. There is a technical limit of 200 attributes per report suite.

section.p: There is no known limit to the number of rows.

ul.li: Lines end with either a CR or CR/LF.
The first column must be a unique customer ID. The ID used should correspond to the ID that is being passed to the Marketing Cloud (Visitor ID) service (or the ID they are storing in a prop or eVar).
Subsequent columns should contain customer attributes that come from the CRM.

Files should include a header on the first line. The name of the first column is not too important, because the system assumes that the first column is the ID column. Subsequent headers should represent the name of each attribute.
Each record should contain the same number of comma-separated fields.
Fields containing a line-break, double-quote, or commas must be quoted.
Double quote characters in a field must be escaped via a backslash (\).
Charset: UTF8
Only primitive data types are allowed with CSV: string, integer, boolean, number.
Blank columns are stored as null.
All fields are required even if they are not set.

section.p: Files uploaded for CRS must adhere to the following naming conventions:
The <filename> portion can be anything though its usually a good idea to include a date stamp in the name.
Files uploaded for CRS must have one of the following extensions:

ul.li: .csv - for CSV files
.json - for JSON files
.aam - for Adobe audience management files

section.p: Files uploaded for CRS can also be compressed with gzip. If compressed, a .gz extension must be appended.
Large files should be split before any compression is applied. When a file is split, a part number should be appended after the filename but before any extensions.
Once a file or file(s) are successfully uploaded, a .fin file should be uploaded to indicate that the uploaded completed successfully. The .fin file should have the same filename as the data files.
Examples of valid filenames:

ul.li: upload_20140622.csv: The filename is upload_20140622 and it is an uncompressed CSV file. The corresponding .fin file is upload_20140622.fin.
upload_20140622.json.gz: The filename upload_20140622 and it is a compressed JSON file. The corresponding .fin file is upload_20140622.fin.

upload_20140622.0.csv.gz, upload_20140622.1.csv.gz, upload_20140622.2.csv.gz, upload_20140622.3.csv.gz: The filename is upload_20140622. It is a compressed CSV file that has been split into four parts. The corresponding .fin file is upload_20140622.fin.

section.p: Guidelines for FTP:

ul.li: File size limit for FTP is 2 GB for each upload.
You should drop your .csv (and .fin) file in the root folder of the FTP site.
If the upload is successful, both files are moved to a folder called "processed".

section.p: Adobe supports FTP and sFTP. To use sFTP, select sFTP in your FTP client, then enter your username and password to connect.
For instructions about setting up sFTP, see Secure File Transfer Protocol.

section.title: Testing Customer Attributes in Adobe Analytics
section.p: The attributes you upload will appear in Adobe Analytics as dimensions and metrics. Using these dimensions and metrics, you will run reports and perform analysis including breakdowns and segmentation. Customer attributes will appear in these Adobe Analytics tools:

ul.li: Reports & analytics
Ad hoc analysis
Reporting API
Report builder

section.title: Beta Testing Requirements
section.p: To participate in the customer attributes beta you must meet the following requirements:

ul.li: Your company must subscribe to either Analytics Standard or Analytics Premium.
Your company must be enabled for the Marketing Cloud and you must have your Marketing Cloud Organization ID.

You must be willing and able to accept the Beta Test Software Agreement, including a confidentiality clause. The Beta Test Software Agreement is a click-through agreement that is presented to you when you log into the beta environment for the first time.
You must upload CRM data to Adobe.
You must set the Customer ID in your Analytics implementation as described above.
Using the selected report suite, your Analytics implementation must synchronize the Customer ID with the Marketing Cloud as describe above.

section.p: Note about Analytics Premium: Some of the functionality you will be testing will be available only to Analytics Premium customers at product release time. However, you are not required to be a Premium customer in order to participate in the beta.

entry.p: When does the beta start?
We anticipate starting the beta in August 2014.
How is this functionality different than what is provided in Analytics premium?

In the past, customers interested in combining customer attribute data with Analytics data have relied heavily on the data workbench tool for this functionality. The customer attributes beta exposes this functionality to a wider audience by providing customer attributes as dimensions and metrics in reports & analytics, ad hoc reporting, and report builder. Analytics Standard customers will have access to customer attributes, but with limited capabilities. The full capabilities will be available to Analytics Premium customers.
Why does Adobe recommend migration to the Visitor ID Service?

Using the Visitor ID service enhances the functionality opens the doors to using the latest and greatest Marketing Cloud functionality, including real-time audiences, the Target/Analytics integration, and video heartbeat tracking.
For more details see Marketing Cloud Visitor ID Service.
Why is it preferable to use the Visitor ID service to set the Customer ID instead of populating the Customer ID in a prop or eVar?
Using the Visitor ID service offers a number of benefits:

ul.li: If you do not set the Customer ID with the Visitor ID service, the customer records are available only to Adobe Analytics. If you want to use the customer records for real-time targeting, you must use the Visitor ID service.

Using the Visitor ID service to set the Customer ID reduces the time it takes to synchronize IDs with the Marketing Cloud. If you put the Customer ID in a prop or eVar, the Customer IDs are sent to the Marketing Cloud via back-end server synchronization that occurs in batches. The Visitor ID service synchronizes the Customer ID with the Marketing Cloud immediately.
Using the Visitor ID service instead of a prop or eVar frees up that prop or eVar for other uses.
We need to test the Visitor ID service with customer attributes during the beta test to ensure it will work properly, so we would appreciate your help in testing it where feasible.

entry.p: If I am already storing a customer ID in a prop or eVar, why would I use this new functionality instead of classifying my prop or eVar with CRM attributes?

Props and eVars are subject to Uniques Exceeded limitations. Using this new beta functionality you can bring in attribute data for an unlimited number of customer IDs. Also, using the prop/eVar approach limits the CRM information to Analytics.
Will DTM help?
If you are already taking advantage of dynamic tag manager, implementing the visitor ID service is greatly simplified.
How does this beta functionality relate to the Master Marketing Profile?

During the beta, you will test a generic data on-boarding tool for the Marketing Cloud that will feed attributes into the Master Marketing Profile (stay tuned for more information). The Master Marketing Profile is a consolidated profile of audience profile and attributes for each visitor that is available for real time targeting use cases.
How does the customer attribute functionality relate to Adobe audience management?

While audience management can receive data to perform audience identification, it cannot perform analytics functionality that ties attributes to historical behavioral data or provide the reporting, analysis, and segmentation capabilities that are available in Adobe Analytics.
How will my CRM attributes appear in Adobe Analytics?

CRM attributes will be manifest in reports & analytics, ad hoc analysis reporting, the reporting API, and report builder. Text attributes will appear as reports/dimensions. Numeric attributes will appear as both dimensions and metrics.
Will the CRM data be available in data warehouse and in data feeds?
The CRM data will not be available in data warehouse or data feeds as a part of this beta or the initial release. These will be added at a later time.
